linkTarget.anchoringText: The workflow allows a comprehensive analysis of the water injection based on the following steps (Fig. 1):

All salinity values were plotted together vs. time, as reported in Fig. 2, showing the wide spread existing in the reservoir (grey dots). Sensible different behaviors can be appreciated for a well producing only formation water during all production life (blue dots), and one where the breakthrough of injected water occurred (red dots). In fact, the former maintains the salinity of the produced water always in the range of the formation water, while the latter shows a clear evidence of a decreasing trend towards lower values due to the breakthrough of injected sea water.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Salinity trend for a well producing formation water (blue dots) and injected water (red dots).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Salinity trend for a well producing formation water (blue dots) and injected water (red dots).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Let us see the application of the methodology to a specific area of the field. In the example reported in Fig. 3 three main periods are identified:

In Fig. 4a are plotted the RFT data in terms of pressure vs. depth. Red lines are the RFT related to the re-pressurization stage (“red” area in Fig. 3) while green lines are those referring to the end of the depletion period (“green” area in Fig. 3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: (a) RFT data plot, (b) Map of the area - Red color refers to the re-pressurization stage, green to the end of the depletion period while yellow is used to highlight the behavior of a well not affected by water injection pressure support.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) RFT data plot, (b) Map of the area - Red color refers to the re-pressurization stage, green to the end of the depletion period while yellow is used to highlight the behavior of a well not affected by water injection pressure support.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Map of the area - Red color refers

linkTarget.anchoringText: The outcome is a connection map as the one reported in Fig. 5.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Connection identification - Red wells are connected producers, black are anhydrous wells (means no water production, no salinity data), light blue are wells producing water with the formation salinity and blue dots is the injector.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Connection identification - Red wells are connected producers, black are anhydrous wells (means no water production, no salinity data), light blue are wells producing water with the formation salinity and blue dots is the injector.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Fig. 6 red areas represent the front of injected water, while blue areas the movement of the aquifer. It is clear the early arrival of the aquifer from W (NW only in the late time), and the influence of injectors on the closest producers.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Evolution in time of the fluid path conceptual model. First timeframe (left) shows the aquifer BT; the second one (central) highlights the effect of injector 1 into two close producers (red wells). The final time step (right) represents the current status of the zone, with areas affected by aquifer (light blue), by injection (red) and by both (overlapping of the two). Green wells are those characterized by mixed water salinity values.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Evolution in time of the fluid path conceptual model. First timeframe (left) shows the aquifer BT; the second one (central) highlights the effect of injector 1 into two close producers (red wells). The final time step (right) represents the current status of the zone, with areas affected by aquifer (light blue), by injection (red) and by both (overlapping of the two). Green wells are those characterized by mixed water salinity values.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 7 shows how history match can significantly improve when the fluid paths are properly reproduced. In the old 3D model, for example, the injector was supporting the producers in W direction, in disagreement with the evidence of the PDA. The resulting match was underestimating the water production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: (a)Old model connections vision; (b)New model connections vision; (c)Old model simulated WC(solid line) and observed WC(dots) vs. time for W-2; (d)New model simulated WC(solid line) and observed WC(dots) vs. time for W-2; (e) New model simulated salinity(solid line) and observed salinity(dots) vs. time for W-2.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a)Old model connections vision; (b)New model connections vision; (c)Old model simulated WC(solid line) and observed WC(dots) vs. time for W-2; (d)New model simulated WC(solid line) and observed WC(dots) vs. time for W-2; (e) New model simulated salinity(solid line) and observed salinity(dots) vs. time for W-2.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Old model simulated WC(solid line) and observed WC(dots) vs. time for W-2
New model simulated WC(solid line) and observed WC(dots) vs. time for W-2
New model simulated salinity(solid line) and observed salinity(dots) vs. time for W-2

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fluid paths conceptual models can provide valuable information about the fault system (Fig. 8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Fault system QC. Faults are those coming from a new seismic interpretation. Red wells produce at low salinity values; light blue show formation water salinity and black ones are anhydrous.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fault system QC. Faults are those coming from a new seismic interpretation. Red wells produce at low salinity values; light blue show formation water salinity and black ones are anhydrous.

linkTarget.anchoringText: More complex situations were clarified as well, such as the one reported in Fig. 9. In this case, the analysis showed a communication through faults between reservoirs separated by shales, highlighted by a strong depletion before the production start-up.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Anomalous depletion of well W-60 and map. The faults involved in this process are highlighted in red, violet and orange. Arrows in the map indicate the top view of the section reported in Fig.10

formatted-caption.caption-text: Anomalous depletion of well W-60 and map. The faults involved in this process are highlighted in red, violet and orange. Arrows in the map indicate the top view of the section reported in Fig.10

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results highlighted that the communication between wells completed on dynamically separated levels (Zone IIIA and IV in Fig.10), was possible through a complex system of faults by sands superposition.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Communication through complex faults scheme between Zone IIIA and IV. Starting from well W-58 (producer in zone IV), the green arrows highlight how passing through the different faults, the interference reached well W-60 (producer in zone IIIA).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Communication through complex faults scheme between Zone IIIA and IV. Starting from well W-58 (producer in zone IV), the green arrows highlight how passing through the different faults, the interference reached well W-60 (producer in zone IIIA).

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Fig. 11, the connections between injectors and producers (highlighted by red areas) show a good communication in the producing zone both in the Northern and Southern areas.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Two main OWCs identified. The grey area represent shale presence.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Two main OWCs identified. The grey area represent shale presence.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 12 shows the salinity behavior in a group of wells, which experienced partialization during the production life. In particular, to reduce the water production, the lower part of the interval (zone II1) was excluded in some wells, based on the assumption of the advancement of a bottom aquifer. Salinity values showed a drastic reduction as soon as the production came only from the upper zone (II), in agreement with the presence of a water injector dedicated to zone II.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Differences on salinity trend for Zone II and II1.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Differences on salinity trend for Zone II and II1.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Anomalies in wells zonation is another outcome of conceptual models. The example reported in Fig. 13 shows that well 4 was directly entering in a formation named “Lower”, without crossing the shallower “Upper” formation, in strong disagreement with the surrounding wells (left side of Fig.13).

The low salinity values showed that well 4 is clearly producing injected water, like the other close wells of the area (Fig. 14). Since the open injector is completed only in the “Upper” zone, the analysis confirmed that well 4 should be open in “Upper” zone as well, and the zonation was accordingly updated in the new geological model (Fig. 13 - right).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Dynamic behavior of wells in the same zone.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dynamic behavior of wells in the same zone.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on the analysis of water breakthrough evidences, a preliminary conceptual model was set-up, showing aquifer arrival from both SW and E directions (Fig. 15a). Nevertheless, significant incongruences were identified. Although the initial period was clearly indicating formation water, the range of values was anomalous, either lower or higher with respect to the aquifer reference salinity for the zone (Fig. 15b). Furthermore, aquifer arrival from SW would imply passing through a fault that in other zones behaved as sealing.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: (a)Fluid path conceptual model based on BT evidences;(b)Salinity values collected for the area.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a)Fluid path conceptual model based on BT evidences;(b)Salinity values collected for the area.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Fluid path conceptual model based on BT evidences
Salinity values collected for the area

linkTarget.anchoringText: A more detailed analysis of salinity values allowed identifying three different well behaviors (Fig. 16b):

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: (a)Reviewed fluid path conceptual model; (b)Salinity data collected and well integrity issues.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a)Reviewed fluid path conceptual model; (b)Salinity data collected and well integrity issues.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Salinity data collected and well integrity issues

linkTarget.anchoringText: The approach is represented in Fig. 17. The location of the commingle well to be analyzed is highlighted in orange on the conceptual model of each involved reservoir, in order to quickly identify which is more in agreement with its production performances.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Zone IIA(a) and Zone IV(b) fluid path conceptual models. Well 63 is the orange square.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Zone IIA(a) and Zone IV(b) fluid path conceptual models. Well 63 is the orange square.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this case, the decreasing trend in salinity associated to the increase in WC was showing the impact of water injection, implying a strong contribution of zone IIA (Fig. 18).

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Salinity(red dots) and WCT(blue dots) of well 63.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Salinity(red dots) and WCT(blue dots) of well 63.
